questions.text: Which of the following statements about Bacillus anthracis is wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: B. anthracis colonies give a frosted glass appearance on blood agar

options.label: B
options.text: B. anthracis forms "strings of pearls" on agar with penicillin

options.label: C
options.text: B. anthracis shows more growth at the bottom of gelatin stab cultures

options.label: D
options.text: PLET medium is used to isolate B. anthracis

questions.correct_answer: C. B. anthracis shows more growth at the bottom of gelatin stab cultures
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Description

Blood Agar
  • Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins, giving a frosted glass appearance. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar.
  • "Medusa head" appearance under microscope.

Agar with Penicillin
  • Susceptible to penicillin.
  • Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml.
  • Forms "string of pearls" chains. (Option B ruled out)

Gelatin Liquefaction





 
  • Obligate aerobe.
  • More growth and energy production at the surface.
  • Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree".

PLET Medium


 
  • Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET)
  • Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli. (Option D ruled out)

Serology



 
  • Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts.
  • DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens.

Laboratory Safety Note
  • High risk of infection from spores.
  • Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male presents with intense pain, swelling, and a foul-smelling discharge from a rapidly worsening wound on his left foot, accompanied by fever and hypotension. Examination reveals crepitus, skin discolouration, and necrosis. Which of the following is most likely the causative organism?
questions.correct_answer: D. C. novyi
questions.explanation:
Organism

Incubation period

C.perferingens

10-48hrs

C.septicum

2-3 days

C.novyi

5-6 days

questions.text: A 65 y/o female presents with severe diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and fever. She has been on clindamycin for the past 10 days to treat a dental infection. O/E, her colonoscopy reveals microabscesses. Stool samples are sent for further testing. Which diagnostic method is considered the gold standard for confirming the suspected infection?
questions.correct_answer: C. ELISA for Toxin Detection
questions.explanation:
Diagnosis

1. Colonoscopy
  • Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses.
  • Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis. (Option A ruled out)

 

2. Culture
  • Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection. (Option B ruled out)

3. Toxin Detection
  • ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard.
  • Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin.

4. Molecular Methods
  • PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples.

5. Histopathology
  • This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains
  • Highly specific but low sensitivity (Option D ruled out)

Treatment

Antibiotic Discontinuation
  • Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Oral vancomycin or metronidazole.
  • Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas.

Prevention

Antibiotic Stewardship
  • Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora.

Infection Control Measures
  • Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings.

Recent Treatment Option

Fecal Transplants
  • Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

questions.text: A 70 y/o patient with a h/o recent hospitalization for hip replacement surgery presents with watery diarrhoea and abdominal cramping. Physical examination reveals mild abdominal tenderness, and laboratory tests show leukocytosis. Stool examination reveals the presence of Clostridioides difficile toxins. What is the most likely risk factor contributing to this patient's condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Prolonged Antibiotic Use

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms primarily contributes to the pathogenicity of Clostridium difficile by disrupting the actin cytoskeleton in cells?
questions.correct_answer: B. Toxins A and B

questions.text: A 35 y/o man presents to the emergency with a 24-hour history of double vision, difficulty swallowing, and generalised weakness.O/E, has diplopia, a diminished gag reflex, and symmetric descending paralysis. He reports that he recently consumed canned vegetables. Which type of botulism is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: C. Foodborne Botulism
questions.explanation:
Foodborne botulism

Wound botulism
  • Bottled and canned food

(Heat Labile toxins)

  • IP: 12-36 hrs
  • Results in
    • Diplopia
    • Dysphagia
    • Dysarthria
    • Descending Flaccid
    • Paralysis
    • Dilated pupils.
    • GI symptoms are also present.
  • IP: 7-10 days
  • No GI symptoms

 

Infant botulism

Iatrogenic botulism
  • Bottle-fed/honey/baby food
  • IP: 1-2 days
  • The first symptom is Constipation.
  • Floppy baby syndrome: flaccid muscles.
  • Surgeries

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which Clostridium botulinum acts?

options.label: A
options.text: Invasion and destruction of muscle tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Production of a toxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions

options.label: C
options.text: Induction of an inflammatory response in peripheral nerves

options.label: D
options.text: Production of a toxin that stimulates excessive acetylcholine release

questions.correct_answer: B. Production of a toxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions

questions.text: A 30-year-old farmer presents with a deep laceration from a farm tool. His last documented tetanus vaccination was 8 years ago. According to current guidelines, what is the appropriate tetanus prophylaxis for this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Administer Td complete series and HTIG

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer Td vaccine only
questions.explanation:
Complete course of vaccine

Not tetanus-prone wound

Tetanus-prone wound*

Taken within 5 years

Nothing required

Nothing required

Taken within >5 to <10 year

Td 1 dose

Td 1 dose

Taken >10 years back

Td 1 dose

Td 1 dose + HTIG

Unknown/incomplete immunization

Td complete dose

Td complete dose + HTIG

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ED with muscle stiffness and spasms. He injured himself with a deep puncture wound while gardening 2 weeks ago; the wound looks necrotic, and he hasn't had a tetanus shot. Lab receives tissue for testing. Which lab finding best indicates Clostridium tetani?

options.label: A
options.text: Gram-positive cocci with clusters and no spore formation on microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: Alpha hemolysis on blood agar, with no concentric swarming movement

options.label: C
options.text: Drumstick-shaped terminal spores with black colour and gas production in Robertson’s cooked meat broth

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid liquefaction of gelatin and no proteolytic reaction in Robertson’s cooked meat broth

questions.correct_answer: C. Drumstick-shaped terminal spores with black colour and gas production in Robertson’s cooked meat broth
questions.explanation:
DIAGNOSIS OF C. TETANI

Specimen
  • Necrotic Tissue

Microscope examination

 
  • Gram +ve Bacilli
  • Spores with Drumstick appearance- Terminal Spores (Option A ruled out)

Blood Agar
  • Alpha hemolysis is produced, which later develops into Beta hemolysis, due to the production of hemolysin (tetanolysin).
  • Concentric movement is seen- Swarming Growth (Option B ruled out)

Robertson's Cooked Meat Broth


 
  • Black colour, gas production
  • Proteolytic reaction (Option D ruled out)

Gelatin stab
  • Fir tree appearance
  • Slow liquefaction

Fildes Technique
  • To obtain pure colonies of C. tetani
  • A test tube is filled with Nutrient broth, and pure colonies can be isolated from the surface.

questions.text: A 50 y/o woman presents with severe muscle pain and stiffness that began 10 days ago after a minor gardening injury. Initially, she had trouble opening her mouth and swallowing, and now she has generalized muscle spasms with an arched back posture. Her vitals show normal BP but increased HR and sweating. Which of the following is NOT a complication of this condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. Muscle weakness in the extremities
questions.explanation:
Clinical Manifestations

Complications
  • Incubation period: 6-10 days
  • A shorter incubation period leads to a graver prognosis
  • Risus sardonicus: Abnormal, sustained spasm of facial muscles producing a grinning appearance (Option A ruled out)
  • Opisthotonos position: Abnormal posture due to generalized spastic contraction of extensor muscles (Option B ruled out)
  • Respiratory muscle spasm: May cause airway obstruction
  • Muscles of the face and jaw are often affected first
  • First symptom: Increase in masseter tone leading to trismus or lockjaw
  • Muscle pain and stiffness
  • Back pain
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • In neonates: Difficulty in feeding
  • Painful muscle spasm: Localized (affected limb) or generalized
  • Descending spastic paralysis
  • Hands and feet spared, mentation unimpaired
  • Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes
  • Autonomic disturbances during the second week:
  • Low or high BP
  • Tachycardia, sweating
  • Intestinal stasis
  • Increased tracheal secretions
  • Acute renal failure (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about tetanospasmin is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Tetanospasmin is responsible for the manifestations of tetanus

options.label: B
options.text: Tetanospasmin is antigenic and can be neutralized by its antitoxin

options.label: C
options.text: Tetanospasmin prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and GABA

options.label: D
options.text: Tetanospasmin is used in its active form for vaccine preparation

questions.correct_answer: D. Tetanospasmin is used in its active form for vaccine preparation
questions.explanation:
Exotoxin

Type

Characteristics

Tetanolysin

Hemolysin
  • Hemolytic activity
  • No role in the Pathogenesis of Tetanus

Tetanospasmin

Neurotoxin
  • Responsible for tetanus (Option A ruled out)
  • Antigenic; Neutralized by antitoxin (Option B ruled out)
  • Plasmid coded
  • Toxin gets toxoided spontaneously or by formaldehyde. The toxoid form is antigenic but loses its virulence property, hence, it is used for vaccine preparation.

Mechanism of Action of Tetanus Toxin:

  • Binds to receptors (polysialogangliosides) on motor nerve terminals, leading to internalization.
  • Transported retrogradely to GABA and glycine-producing inhibitory neuron terminals.
  • Prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine and GABA). (Option C ruled out)
  • Results in spastic muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 50 y/o male presents with severe pain, swelling, and crepitus in his left thigh following a traumatic injury. Laboratory tests, including a Nagler's reaction, return positive, indicating a clostridial infection. Which of the following organisms does not test positive for Nagler’s reaction?
questions.correct_answer: A. C. tetani
questions.explanation:
Organism

Microscopic appearance

C. Perfringens

Thick, stubby, boxcar-shaped, gram-positive bacilli without spore

C. septicum

Citron bodies (boat or leaf-shaped pleomorphic irregularly stained bacilli with spores)

C. novyi

Large rods with oval sub-terminal spores

Method

Properties

Robertson cooked meat medium
  • Transport as well as culture media
  • C.perferingens tolerates heat and can grow when incubated at 45°C for 4-6 hrs
  • Shows a pink and turbid appearance

Litmus Milk



 
  • Produces “stormy clot reaction”
  • Fermentation of lactose-producing acid and vigorous gas

Nagler’s reaction
  • Produces an opalescence surrounding the streak line on egg yolk agar or media containing 20% human serum (due to lecithinase activity of α-toxin).
  • Opalescence is inhibited by incorporating anti-α-toxin into the medium.
  • Positive for C. bifermentans, C. baratti, and C. sordellii (all produce α-toxin) (Option B, C, D ruled out)

Target hemolysis

 
  • Double zone hemolysis
  • On blood agar, it produces an inner narrow zone of complete hemolysis (due to θ-toxin)
  • Surrounded by a much wider zone of incomplete hemolysis (due to the alpha-toxin)

Reverse CAMP test

 
  • C.perfringens is streaked over the centre of the blood agar plate
  • Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked perpendicular to it
  • The presence of an enhanced zone of hemolysis (arrow-shaped) pointing toward C. perfringens indicates the test is positive

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhoea after consuming a large meal of pork. Imaging and laboratory results suggest enteritis necroticans. Which of the following organisms cause enteritis necroticans?
questions.correct_answer: C. C. perferingens type C
questions.explanation:
Type of infection

Features

Food poisoning
  • Caused by C. perfringens type A enterotoxin
  • Consumption of improperly cooked meat
  • Requires 10^8 viable vegetative bacilli for infection to occur.
  • Diagnosis by detection of enterotoxin in faeces

Enteritis necroticans
  • Caused by C. perfringens type C strains, producing β toxin
  • Gas gangrene of the bowel
  • Ischemic necrosis of the jejunum and gas in the tissue plane
  • PIGBEL (papa new guinea)- abdominal pain and diarrhoea following unaccustomed feasting on pig meat along with trypsin inhibitors like sweet potatoes.

Necrotising enterocolitis
  • C. perfringens type A (Option A ruled out)
  • Resembles enteritis necroticans

Gangrenous appendicitis
  • C. perfringens type A

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of Bacillus anthracis?

options.label: B
options.text: It produces beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar

options.label: C
options.text: It is generally susceptible to penicillin

options.label: D
options.text: It produces anthrax toxin, which includes protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor

questions.correct_answer: B. It produces beta-hemolytic colonies on blood agar
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Bacillus anthracis

Bacillus cereus

Hemolysis on Sheep Blood Agar

Non-hemolytic

Hemolytic (Option B)

Motility

Non-motile

(Option A ruled out)

Motile

Penicillin susceptibility

Sensitive

(Option C ruled out)

Resistant

Lecithinase Production

+

+

Gelatin hydrolysis

-

+

Growth in Penicillin agar (10 U/mL)

-

+

Growth on phenyl ethyl alcohol agar

-

+

questions.text: A 60 y/o male presents with severe pain, swelling, and a foul-smelling discharge from a wound on his leg sustained three days ago.O/E the affected area has signs of necrosis, raising suspicion of gas gangrene. Which of the following toxins is responsible for toxaemia in gas gangrene?
questions.correct_answer: A. Alpha toxin
questions.explanation:
Major Toxin

Uses

1. Alpha

  • Most important toxin
  • Responsible for toxemia in gas gangrene
  • Dermonecrotic and hemolytic
  • Naglers reaction -Phospholipase in the presence of Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions split into phosphorylcholine and diglyceride-opalescence in Serum or egg yolk media

2. Beta (Option B ruled out)
  • Lethal and necrotising properties

3. Epsilon

4. Iota

Minor toxin

Uses

1. Gamma (Option C ruled out)
  • Minor lethal action

2. Eta

3. Delta
  • Lethal effect
  • Hemolytic for the red cells of even-toed ungulates (sheep, goats, pigs, cattle)

4. Theta (Option D ruled out)
  • Oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to streptolysin 0
  • Lethal and a general cytolytic toxin

5. Kappa
  • Collagenase

6. Lamba
  • Proteinase
  • Gelatinase

7. Mu
  • Hyaluronidase

8. Nu
  • Deoxyribonuclease

Enzymes

Uses

Neuraminidase
  • Destroys myxovirus receptors on RBCs

Bursting Factor
  • Specific action on muscle tissue
  • Muscle lesions in gas gangrene

Circulating Factor
  • Increase in adrenaline sensitivity of capillary bed
  • Inhibit phagocytosis

Haemagglutinin
  • Active against the red blood cells of human beings and most animals

Other enzymes include

  • Histamine, Fibrinolysin, hemolysin

questions.text: A 58 y/o farmer presented to the casualty with ℅ high fever and chills for the last 5 days.O/E there are no obvious sources of infection. A blood culture was obtained and the patient was diagnosed with PUO. Gram staining revealed characteristic “Tennis racket appearance”. Which of the following is the likely organism causing this infection?
questions.correct_answer: B. C. tertium
questions.explanation:
Species

Spore position &shape

Clostridium perfringens

(Option A ruled out)

Subterminal -club-shaped

Clostridium tetani

(Option D ruled out)

Spherical and terminal -drumstick

Clostridium tertium
(Option B)

Oval and terminal - tennis racket

Clostridium bifermentans

(Option C ruled out)

Central and oval-spindle-shaped

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Clostridium species is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Most Clostridium species are encapsulated and non-motile

options.label: B
options.text: C. perfringens is both encapsulated and non-motile

options.label: D
options.text: Clostridium species generally exhibit rapid movement due to peritrichate flagella

questions.correct_answer: B. C. perfringens is both encapsulated and non-motile
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Details

Unencapsulated and Motile
  • Most Clostridium species fall into this category (Option A ruled out)

Encapsulated Species
  • C. perfringens
  • C. butyricum

Non-motile Species
  • C. perfringens (Option C ruled out)
  • C. tetani type VI

Motility
  • The majority are motile by peritrichate flagella (flagella attached in multiple locations). (Option D ruled out)
  • This includes C. butyricum. (Option B)
  • Movement described as "stately" due to its slowness (Option D)

questions.text: A 30 y/o man arrives at the ER with symptoms of food poisoning, including severe nausea and vomiting, after eating fried rice from a local restaurant 5 hours ago. Which statement about Bacillus cereus food poisoning is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Symptoms of emetic form typically manifest within 8-16 hours after ingestion

options.label: B
options.text: The emetic form of B. cereus food poisoning is associated with consuming contaminated meat and poultry

options.label: C
options.text: Diagnosis of B. cereus can be confirmed by finding more than >10 5 cells per gram of food or stool culture

options.label: D
options.text: B. cereus grows anaerobically at 37°C on sheep blood agar

questions.correct_answer: C. Diagnosis of B. cereus can be confirmed by finding more than >10 5 cells per gram of food or stool culture
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Details


 

Food Poisoning
  • Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic.
  • Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion. (Option B ruled out)
  • Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare)
  • Emetic form: Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice; nausea and vomiting within 1-5 hours. (Option A ruled out)
  • Some cases may include diarrhoea

Other Infections
  • Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis
  • More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients

Diagnostic Method

Details

Food Poisoning
  • Culture of implicated food essential.
  • >105 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis.
  • Quantitative stool cultures with at least 105 cells per gram support diagnosis.

Culture Characteristics
  • Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar. (Option D ruled out)
  • β-hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance.
  • Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin

Selective Media
  • MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources

Microscopy
  • Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli.
  • Motile

questions.text: A 38 y/o biologist returns from a field expedition in an anthrax-endemic area, displaying symptoms and skin lesions indicative of cutaneous anthrax. Lab tests confirm the diagnosis. Which statement about the treatment of cutaneous anthrax is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral administration of fluoroquinolones or doxycycline for 7-14 days is recommended

options.label: B
options.text: Combined therapy with antibiotics and anthrax immunoglobulin is necessary

options.label: C
options.text: Human Anthrax Immunoglobulin (Anthrasil) is used as an antitoxin option

options.label: D
options.text: Treatment includes a combination of at least three antimicrobial drugs, including clindamycin

questions.correct_answer: B. Combined therapy with antibiotics and anthrax immunoglobulin is necessary
questions.explanation:
Clinical Presentation

Recommended Treatment

Uncomplicated Cutaneous Anthrax
  • Oral fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin) or doxycycline for 7-14 days (Option A ruled out)

Pulmonary and Intestinal Anthrax
  • Combined therapy with antibiotics and anthrax immunoglobulin due to higher fatality risk

Systemic Anthrax
  • Antitoxin treatment alongside antimicrobial drugs to neutralize B. anthracis toxin effects.

Antitoxin Options
  • Human Anthrax Immunoglobulin (Anthrasil). (Option C ruled out)
  • Monoclonal Antibodies (Obiltoxaximab, Raxibacumab)

Anthrax Meningitis
  • Combination therapy with at least three antimicrobial drugs including clindamycin for 60 days (Option D ruled out)

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)
  • Ciprofloxacin and doxycycline for 60 days.
  • AVA BioThrax vaccine to enhance immune response

questions.text: A 45 y/o veterinarian presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. He has been working in an area with a recent outbreak of anthrax among livestock. He discusses the precautions he takes and the vaccines available to him. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the precautions and vaccines for Bacillus anthracis?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a biosafety level II/III cabinet is essential.

options.label: B
options.text: Autopsies on animals suspected of anthrax are recommended

options.label: C
options.text: Workers in industries handling animal products should wear protective clothing

options.label: D
options.text: The BioThrax vaccine is considered safe and effective for human use

questions.correct_answer: B. Autopsies on animals suspected of anthrax are recommended
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Biosafety Level
  • Use biosafety level II/III cabinets to handle specimens. (Option A ruled out)

Handling Suspected Carcasses
  • Discouraged to prevent soil contamination with spores.
  • Safer alternatives: blood samples or a cut ear.
  • Proper disposal: deep burial in quicklime or cremation

Decontamination of Animal Products
  • Decontaminate suspected products via autoclaving.
  • Workers should wear protective clothing and gloves. (Option C ruled out)

Duckering
  • Disinfect wool: 2% formaldehyde solution at 30-40°C for 20 minutes.
  • Animal hair and bristles: 0.25% formaldehyde solution at 60°C for six hours

Types of Vaccines

Details

Live Attenuated, Non-encapsulated Spore Vaccine (Sterne Vaccine)
  • Used in animals.
  • Effective for about one year after a single injection.
  • Not safe for human use

Adsorbed (alum-precipitated) Toxoid Vaccine
  • Uses protective antigens to trigger immune response.
  • Safe and effective for human use
  • Eg. BioThrax (Option D ruled out)

Pasteur's Anthrax Vaccine
  • Historically significant, Developed by Louis Pasteur in 1881

Mazzucchi Vaccine
  • Uses spores from the attenuated Carbazoo strain combined with 2% saponin

Category

Details

Pre-exposure
  • High-risk individuals (e.g., veterinarians, lab personnel).
  • Five-dose regimen followed by boosters

Post-exposure
  • Administer alongside antibiotic treatment.
  • For suspected or confirmed inhalation anthrax exposure

questions.text: Match the following and choose the correct option: Name Microscopy a. Bacillus anthracis 1. b.Vibrio cholerae 2. c. Corynebacterium diphtheria 3. d. McFadyean’s Reaction 4.
questions.explanation:
Name

Microscopy

Features

a. Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large (3-10 µm x 1-1.6 µm), rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

It is

b.Vibrio Cholerae
  • Gram-negative
  • Non-acid fast
  • Short, curved cylindrical rod.
  • Distinctive comma shape.
  • Motile: propelled by a single-sheathed polar flagellum.
  • Shows fish in stream appearance.

c. Corynebacterium diphtheria
  • Slender
  • Rod-shaped
  • Gram-positive bacterium
  • Clubbed at one or both ends.
  • Typically in pairs, palisades, or small groups,
  • Often forming angles resembling the letters V or L, known as a Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement

d. McFadyean’s Reaction

The capsule of Bacillus Anthracis can be visualized using McFadyean's reaction, in which a smear is stained with polychrome methylene blue. The capsule stains purple, while the bacterial cells stain blue.

questions.text: A patient presents with a black necrotic lesion on their arm, surrounded by swelling and secondary vesicles. They report handling animal hides recently. What is the most likely diagnosis and the route of transmission?

options.label: A
options.text: Cutaneous anthrax, spores entered through damaged skin

questions.correct_answer: A. Cutaneous anthrax, spores entered through damaged skin

questions.text: A patient infected with Bacillus anthracis presents with severe oedema and systemic symptoms. Which combination of virulence factors is primarily responsible for these clinical manifestations?

options.label: B
options.text: Protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor

questions.correct_answer: B. Protective antigen, oedema factor, and lethal factor
questions.explanation:
Correct answer B) Protective antigen, edema factor, and lethal factor

Virulence Factor of Bacillus Anthracis

Capsule

Exotoxin
  • The capsule is composed of poly-D-glutamic acid, which is different from the polysaccharide capsules found in most other bacteria.
  • It protects against phagocytosis.
  • The capsule is encoded by a plasmid.
  • If this plasmid is lost, the strain will become avirulent.
  • It is composed of protective antigen (PA), oedema factor (EF), and lethal factor (LF).
  • These proteins are nontoxic individually but work together to cause harmful effects.
  • The genes encoding anthrax toxin are carried on a plasmid.
  • PA binds to cell receptors and forms a membrane channel, which allows for the entry of EF and LF into the cell.
  • EF is an adenylate cyclase that causes oedema.
  • LF, when combined with PA, forms a lethal toxin. Lethal toxin is a major virulence factor and is the cause of death in infected people and animal.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Bacillus anthracis are true? Bacillus anthracis was the first pathogenic bacterium to be seen under a microscope It was the first communicable disease demonstrated to be transmitted by the inoculation of infected blood It was the first bacillus to be isolated in pure culture and shown to possess spores The anthrax vaccine was the first live attenuated bacterial vaccine prepared.
questions.correct_answer: D. All statements are correct
